page.title: 18LONGFORGAN - CHANGES -
page.content: In 1920 the majority of the houses had thatched roofs, no toilets or inside water supply. Water was carried from wells in the village street. Only eight of the larger houses had inside conveniences. There was no electricity or street lighting in the village. Houses were lit by candles or paraffin lamps. Cooking was done on the open, solid fuel kitchen range. There were no tarmac roads, no school jotters - only slates and slate pencils for the children to use. There were no buses, so all the people going to Dundee had to walk daily to and from the station to get the train. There were no televisions, radios or telephones. Communications were done by telegram. Horse carriers brought goods from Dundee twice a week for the village shops, and the rail porters made their deliveries by hand barrows.
